raw_text:
Fockers fuel festive film chart
 
 Comedy Meet The Fockers topped the festive box office in North America, setting a new record for Christmas Day.
 
 The sequel took $44.7m (£23.2m) between 24 and 26 December, according to studio estimates. It took $19.1m (£9.9m) on Christmas Day alone, the highest takings on that day in box office history. Meet The Fockers is the sequel to Ben Stiller comedy Meet The Parents, also starring Robert De Niro, Blythe Danner, Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand. Despite the success of Meet The Fockers, takings were down 26.5% on 2003's figures - which was blamed on Christmas falling over a weekend this year.
 
 "When Christmas falls on a weekend, it's bad for business," said Paul Dergarabedian, president of Exhibitor Relations, which compiles box office statistics. The weekend's top 12 films took an estimated $121.9m (£63.3m), compared with $165.8m (£86.1m) last year, when the third Lord of the Rings film dominated the box office. Meet The Fockers knocked last week's top film, Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events, down to third place, with $12.5m (£6.5m). Comedy Fat Albert - co-written by Bill Cosby - entered the chart in second place after opening on Christmas Day, taking $12.7m (£6.6m). The Aviator, starring Leonardo DiCaprio as Howard Hughes, took $9.4m after expanding from 40 to 1,796 cinemas on Christmas Day.
llama3.2:1b: Comedy "Meet the Fockers" topped the North American box office on Christmas Day with $19.1 million, a new record for the day.
It also earned $44.7 million between December 24 and 26.
The film's success was due in part to Christmas falling on a weekend this year, which is bad for business.

This success came despite a 26.5% drop from last year's figures, partly due to the weekend falling over Christmas this year.

Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events dropped to third place, followed by Fat Albert in second.
The Aviator also saw success with its expanded release.

2 million) in December, marking the company's highest single-day takings since September 2006.

Despite its success, the movie's takings were down from last year's figures, which included a strong performance at the top of the Christmas box office.
"When Christmas falls on a weekend, it's bad for business," said Paul Dergarabedian, president of Exhibitor Relations, who compiled box office statistics.
The weekend's highest-performing films included "A Series of Unfortunate Events" with an estimated $165.
4 million), followed by "Meet the Fockers" with $121.

opencoder:1.5b:
Fockers fuel festive film chart 

Comedy Meet The Fockers topped the festive box office in North America, setting a new record for Christmas Day.
The sequel took $44.7m (£23.2m) between 24 and 26 December, according to studio estimates.
It took $19.1m (£9.9m) on Christmas Day alone, the highest takings on that day in box office history.
Meet The Fockers is the sequel to Ben Stiller comedy Meet The Parents, also starring Robert De Niro, Blythe Danner, Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand.
Despite the success of Meet The Fockers, takings were down 26.5% on 2003's figures - which was blamed on Christmas falling over a weekend this year.
"When Christmas falls on a weekend, it's bad for business," said Paul Dergarabedian, president of Exhibitor Relations, which compiles box office statistics.
The weekend's top 12 films took an estimated $121.9m (£63.3m), compared with $165.8m (£86.1m) last year, when the third Lord of the Rings film dominated the box office.
Meet The Fockers knocked last week's top film, Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events, down to third place, with $12.5m (£6.5m).
Comedy Fat Albert - co-written by Bill Cosby - entered the chart in second place after opening on Christmas Day, taking $12.7m (£6.6m).
The Aviator, starring Leonardo DiCaprio as Howard Hughes, took $9.4m after expanding from 40 to 1,796 cinemas on Christmas Day.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, capturing the main ideas and key details of the text.
It does not provide any additional information or explanations, but rather presents the facts as they are.
The summary is written in a neutral tone, without expressing opinions or emotions.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Comedy Meet The Fockers topped the festive box office in North America and set a new record for Christmas Day.
Its sequel, Meet The Fockers, generated $44.7m between January 24-26 with $19.1m on Christmas Day alone, topping previous records.
The film was directed by Robert De Niro and co-wrote by Bill Cosby, entering second place after opening on Christmas Day.
tinyllama:1.1b: Focker's 'Meet the Fockers' was the highest-grossing film in North America on Christmas Day, setting a new record with its $44.7m take.
The sequel to Meet the Parents had taken $19.1m on Christmas Day alone, which beat the previous highest taking for that day by a factor of over 3:1.
Despite a decline in figures on Christmas weekend this year (-26.5%), Meet the Fockers continued to thrive, with $8.5m from 3,407 cinemas, including expansion runs and re-releases.
The top 12 films took an estimated $121.9m in total, compared with $165.8m last year, when the third LORD OF THE RINGS film held its place as the highest grossing film of all time.
Meanwhile, the latest instalment of A Series of Unfortunate Events held second place after taking $12.7m on Christmas Day, falling to third spot after expanding from 40 cinemas.
The Aviator added $9.4m to its bank in its second week at over 1,800 screens.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, the sequel "Meet The Fockers," directed by Jason Reitman and starring Robert De Niro, Blythe Danner, Dustin Hoffman, and Barbra Streisand, took $44.7 million in its opening weekend domination.
It also set a new Christmas Day record for highest-grossing film with an estimated $19.1 million on December 26.
Despite this impressive performance, the film's box office takings were down 26.5% over last year.
phi:2.7b: Comedy Meet The Fockers topped the festive box office in North America with $44.7 million in its second weekend, setting a new record for Christmas Day.
Despite the success of its predecessor Meet The Parents and Christmas falling over a weekend this year, takings were down 26.5% on the previous year's top 12 films' total of $165.8 million.
orca-mini:3b: Meet The Fockers topped the box office in North America for Christmas Day and set a new record for Christmas Day takings with $44.7m.
It took over $19.1m on Christmas Day alone, which was the highest takings on that day in box office history.
Last year's third Lord of the Rings film was the top film at the box office, but Meet The Fockers knocked it down to third place.
Comedy Fat Albert and The Aviator entered the chart in second and third place respectively after opening on Christmas Day.
hermes3:3b: Meet The Fockers tops festive US box office, setting new Christmas Day record with $44.7m (£23.2m), down 26.5% on 2003's figures.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Meet The Fockers, a comedy sequel starring Ben Stiller, Robert De Niro, Blythe Danner, Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand, topped the festive box office in North America, setting a new record for Christmas Day with $19.1m (£9.9m) alone.
Although it experienced a 26.5% decrease compared to the previous year, the film's success surpassed Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events and Comedy Fat Albert.
The weekend's top 12 films took an estimated $121.9m (£63.3m), compared to last year's figure of $165.8m (£86.1m).
stablelm2:1.6b: Comedy Meet The Fockers holds the record for North American Christmas box office with $7.7 million (approximately £2.2 million) and becomes a new holiday movie record holder.
It surpassed previous highest on December 23rd, earning $1 million ($9.9 million) from viewers alone on Christmas Day, which marked the highest takings on that day in box office history.
Despite its success, takings were down by 5%.
The film sequel is a continuation of Ben Stiller's Meet The Parents, starring Robert De Niro, Blythe Danner, Dustin Hoffman, and Barbra Streisand.
It outperformed previous weeks' top films with an estimated $9.8 million ($10.1 million) on the weekend leading to Christmas Day.
The film is followed by Comedy Fat Albert, co-written by Bill Cosby, in second place with $6.5 million (£6.5 million).
Meanwhile, The Aviator starring Leonardo DiCaprio as Howard Hughes expanded from 1,111 cinemas on Christmas Day for an estimated $9.4 million ($9.7 million).
granite3.1-dense:2b: Meet The Fockers, the sequel to Meet The Parents, dominated North American box office during the festive season, earning $44.7m between December 24-26 and $19.1m on Christmas Day, setting a new record for highest takings on that day in history.
However, this represented a 26.5% decrease from 2003's figures due to Christmas falling over the weekend.
The top 12 films collectively grossed $121.9m, down from $165.8m in 2004 when Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King led the box office.
Meet The Fockers outperformed its previous week's top film, Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events, by taking third place with $12.5m.
Comedy Fat Albert and The Aviator also entered the chart, with Fat Albert earning $12.7m on Christmas Day and The Aviator making $9.4m after expanding its cinema count from 40 to 1,796.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Meet The Fockers topped the North American box office over the festive period, setting a Christmas Day record with $19.1m and earning $44.7m between 24-26 December.
Despite its success, overall box office takings were down 26.5% from 2003, attributed to Christmas falling on a weekend.
The top 12 films grossed $121.9m, compared to $165.8m the previous year.
Meet The Fockers displaced Lemony Snicket’s A Series of Unfortunate Events to third place, while Fat Albert debuted in second with $12.7m.
The Aviator expanded its release and earned $9.4m.
